COMMENT_TX: Great play; Traynor took the topper between hops and threw him out by five feet.
Hit on the right arm by a fast ball; he was in great pain. The doctor rushed out to examine him.
Grantham had to reach for the throw
Hit & run; wide throw prevented DP
Struck out on a wide fast ball
Meadows threw nothing but curve balls the entire inning
Remarkable stop back of 2B but late throw
Smith had to duck the 0-2 pitch
Struck out on a fast ball around his neck
Great diving catch was ruled a trap by Ump McCormick
Grantham fell but made the play while lying on the ground
Good throw made play at the plate close
Leaping catch by Moore of high throw before applying tag
Pretty 1-hand stab by Grantham of Traynor's wide throw
Rice was half way to 2B when balk was called
The sky was now becoming overcast with a pall of smoke
DP ball but Harris dropped it after getting the out at 2B
Swung at strike three that was in the dirt
Beautiful stop and quick throw; Goslin claimed the high throw drew Grantham off the bag.
Traynor leaped for it and knocked it down
High looping hit over the temporary screen in front of the LF scoreboard.
Ruel picked it off a fan's hat near Judge Landis

Hit above the left ear and dropped to the ground.  Players and a doctor rushed to his assistance.  After a few minutes he sat up holding his head in his hands.  When he rose he was dazed, very unsteady, and was helped off the field. Bluege was not injured seriously, the physicians believed, but it left him quite dizzy.
Nearly took Aldridge's hand off; he stopped it and recovered in time to make a close play at 1B.
BOUNCE HR past J.Harris and into RCF stands on one hop
Moore juggled it, hesitated, then threw to 1B
Wintry winds The wind was blowing the dust around the field
The pitch struck him on the back
Goslin almost dropped it; high wind made it hard to gauge
The dust was worse this inning, blowing right and left

DWS: from NYT: 'Goslin struck out, but Smith let the third strike go past him to the grandstand and Smith thought the ball had been fouled and did not go after it.  Goslin ran to second while Kremer chased the ball. Manager McKechnie and the Pittsburgh players protested to McCormick that it was a foul, but the decision stood. After Kremer had pitched a strike over to Judge the umpires held a conference and decided that Goslin should go back to first base.'  N/C and TB both have a PB and an error on this play.  NYT box score has PB, but no error. I'm leaving what John did, namely a PB but no error. PDT/PGT: After the ump conference the one strike was also withdrawn.  The official scorer had given Smith an error with his PB but retracted the error a few batters later. WP: Before Game 4, official scorers retracted the PB and charged Smith with an error instead.
Low liner got away from J.Harris attempting shoestring catch
Smith and other Pirates kicked on ball three and four
Weather grew colder as the game went on
Stretched it by fast running; caught Rice by surprise. Close play at 2B as Peck applied tag.
BOUNCE HR; it bounced 10 feet in front of RCF bleachers and bounded into the crowd.
Carey had trouble gauging it in the wind
Just out of Moore's reach near second
Myer hit by his own batted ball DWS: The rules of the day give the putout to no one, but I gave it to the catcher

Controversial play as Rice leaned into the bleachers to make what seemed to be one of the most remarkable catches ever seen in a World Series game.  A running, leaping, twisting, acrobatic catch. Rice failed to return the ball immediately and the Pirates argued unsuccessfully to Ump Rigler that a fan gave him the ball.
$Marberry batted here; should have been McNeely, but the Pirates did not notice the batting out of turn
Hit on the left arm WP: Hit on the back
Johnson injured his right leg on the way to 2B.  He had it bandaged up and played in pain for the rest of the game.
Pretty diving stop but no play
BOUNCE HR; hopped into LF bleachers on the first bounce. Over Barnhart and into the temporary seats in front of the concrete bleachers.
Landed halfway up LF bleachers; the most prodigious blow of the Series.
Beat Judge's throw to Harris by a fraction
Too late for the force at second, but in time at first
Twisting Texas Leaguer eluded Wright, Barnhart, and Carey
DP failed when Grantham couldn't get back to the bag in time
Attempted double steal; extremely close play at the plate. Harris strongly protested the decision.
Ball four hit him but scored a walk
Harris tagged Barnhart and Judge caught Bucky's wide throw and tagged Traynor.

Washington Post article on pitch counts: Johnson=120; Yde=56, Morrison=71, Adams=16 These differ from the pitch-by-pitch account in same paper The Post article also indicated non-contact strikes: Johnson=33; Yde=13, Morrison=25, Adams=5 ...and foul balls (including those caught): Johnson=16; Yde=4, Morrison=5, Adams=2 ...and called balls: Johnson=40; Yde=22, Morrison=22, Adams=4
Pirate infield came in to protest ball four to Ump Rigler
Carey was hurt colliding with Harris and needed several minutes before resuming play.
Attempted double steal; Cuyler made it back to 3B
Great diving stop by Judge who then crawled to the bag
Into LF stands about 3 rows back
Peck juggled it then threw wildly
Attempted double steal; Ruel faked throw to 2B
Into the permanent seats in RF
Over McInnis; hit & run.  Cuyler was playing over toward CF. Bluege slid home under the throw.
Wright just beat DP relay to 1B
Leaping catch by McInnis of high throw
Bouncer over the mound to Peckinpaugh, who stepped on 2B; Ump Moriarty called Moore safe and a violent protest ensued.
Over the temporary fence in LF in front of the scoreboard
Off the screen in front of temporary seats in LCF
With 1-1 count, time was called to have the field along the RF stands cleared.  A broken rail from one of the temporary boxes had fallen onto the field.
Fine pickup by McInnis of low throw
Game was held up between innings so carpenters could work on the broken field box.
There was a disturbance in LF halting play until the police arrived to keep the bleacherites back.
Due to the confusion in Game 3 when WS1 batted out of turn, the umpires called B.Harris to the plate so they would know just how his new men were going to bat.
Tremendous smash off the screen in the deepest corner of CF. It came within 3' of being a home run.

Washington Post article on pitch counts: Kremer=132; Ferguson=89, Ballou=13 These differ from the pitch-by-pitch account in same paper Post also indicated non-contact strikes: Kremer=45; Ferguson=33, Ballou=4 ...and foul balls: Kremer=17; Ferguson=8, Ballou=N/A ...and called balls: Kremer=48; Ferguson=32, Ballou=6
It rained most of the game, making the field a mass of tricky, sticky mud.  The outfield was filled with puddles. Burned gasoline had removed most of the surface moisture from the infield.
A walk with the bases loaded did not always get an RBI until 1927 However, it seems fairer to give them out - Palmer
Off the top of the LF screen; near HR

A voluble and violent protest ensued at the plate by PIT. DWS: the interference removed the 64 force out that had happened.  The NYT box doesn't give Smith an error, nor do N/C or TB.  However, they agree that Peckinpaugh  doesn't get an at bat either.  We have to have the error although it appears that a catcher error on this play isn't in the rules until 1951. He was given an RBI on the play, since the run would have scored if the force out had stood - Pete Palmer
Wide throw but Judge caught it off the bag then dove back
Texas Leaguer; Cuyler made a sensational diving catch, somersaulted, then threw past McInnis who wasn't looking for a throw.
The ball stuck in the marshy ground when it fell
Off the bleacher fence in LCF
Harris' relay to 1B pulled Judge off the bag
As the 4th inning started, the drizzle and low-hanging clouds made it virtually impossible to see the ball.
McInnis had to make a falling catch of the throw
Caught near the boxes back of 3B
Hard running catch after Cuyler nearly misjudged it
Goslin had his glove on it right against the fence but dropped it.  WS1 insisted the ball was foul.
Dark clouds/fog descended and it became difficult to see
Skipped past Rice to the fence; close play at home
Into LF stands, over the barrier in front of the scoreboard

Rain came down harder; Traynor gave Wright a towel to wipe off his bat.  Johnson asked for some sawdust for the pitcher's box.  He filled his cap with sawdust and took it back himself.  The mound was very slippery.
It was still raining hard and getting darker; the game was held up while more sawdust was spread about the pitcher's box.
Long fly to RF corner rolled under the canvas stored there

Washington Post article on pitch counts: Johnson=130; Aldridge=25, Morrison=69, Kremer=31, Oldham=12 These differ from the pitch-by-pitch account in same paper Post also indicated non-contact strikes: Johnson=29; Aldridge=5, Morrison=21, Kremer=9, Oldham=6 ...and foul balls (including foul-outs): Johnson=15; Aldridge=1, Morrison=7, Kremer=5, Oldham=2 ...and called balls: Johnson=43; Aldridge=13, Morrison=25, Kremer=6, Oldham=3
